title: What were the primary sources of synergies for Expand Energy Corp (NASDAQ: EXE)'s merger with Southwestern Energy, and how have the projected synergies changed over time since the announcement of the merger?
description:
First, take note of the primary sources of synergies that were cited when the merger was announced: “annual operational and overhead synergies of approximately $400 million” driven by longer laterals, lower drilling and completion costs, G&A reductions, and utilization of shared operational infrastructure.
 
 Then, take note of the initial synergy target per year when the deal was announced in January 2024: ~$400 M per year (run-rate) of operational and overhead synergies.
 
 Then, take note of the first guidance update in October 2024, which raised the annual synergy target by $100 M to $500 M annually by the end of FY 2027.
 
 There was another guidance update in October 2025, increasing the total annual synergy outlook to $600 M by the end of FY 2026 and was on track to hit $500 M by the end of FY 2025.
answer:
Primary synergy sources were longer laterals, lower drilling and completion costs, G&A reductions, and the utilization of shared operational infrastructure.
 
 The merger was originally expected to generate $400 M in annual synergies, but that figure has since been revised to $500 M for FY 2025 and $600 M for FY 2026.
